choices.text: Failure of the left lateral palatine process to fuse with the median palatine process
Failure of the left maxillary prominence to unite with the left medial nasal prominence
Failure of the right and left medial nasal prominences to merge
Failure of the right palatine process to fuse with the left palatine process

questions.text: A 6-week-old infant has been presented with an anomaly depicted in the provided image. This abnormality arises from the lack of fusion between which anatomical structures?
questions.solution:
Failure of the left maxillary prominence to unite with the left medial nasal prominence

  1. Cleft lip: Cleft lip is a congenital cleft or defect in the upper lip, usually due to complete or partial failure of migration and deposit of mesoderm around or over the head in the embryo, with consequent failure of the maxillary prominence to merge with the merged medial nasal prominences
  2. Failure of the left lateral palatine process to fuse with the median palatine process: unilateral cleft palate
  3. Failure of the right palatine process to fuse with the left palatine process: midline posterior cleft palate
  4. Failure of the right and left medial nasal prominences to merge: midline cleft lip

questions.text: A 5 years old child presented with absence or thymus, hypoparathyroidism and tetany. Which of the following marked area is defective in this case?
questions.solution: Absence of thymus, hypoparathyroidism and tetany (suggestive of developmental anomaly of parathyroid) is suggestive of Di-George syndrome, which results from dysmorphogenesis of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches during early embryogenesis, leading to hypoplasia or aplasia of the thymus and parathyroid glands and signs and symptoms of hypocalcemia.

questions.text: The given image is showing the histology of cartilage. Identify the type of cartilage?
questions.solution: The given image shows chondroblasts and larger chondrocytes are embedded in the matrix blue- black elastin fibres suggestive of elastic cartilage. Elastic cartilage present in external ear, corniculate cartilages, epiglottis and apices of the arytenoids.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male reports symptoms of pain, numbness, and fatigue in the right arm. Angiography discloses reduced blood flow in vessels anastomosing near the surgical neck of the humerus. The pathology is most likely associated with which of the following arteries?
questions.solution: The branches of the third part of the axillary artery supply the surgical neck of the humerus. Thrombus in this part will cause decreased supply in its branches - the anterior and posterior circumflex humeral arteries.

questions.text: A 46 - year old man fell down from the stairs. He was feeling severe pain in right shoulder. He was taken to the emergency OPD. On examination the doctor observed that the officer was sitting on the chair with the arm by the side of his body and he was supporting his right elbow with his left hand. The inspection of right shoulder revealed loss of its normal rounded contour and loss of skin sensation in the lower half of the deltoid region. Any attempt to perform active or passive movement was stopped by severe pain in shoulder. Which of the following nerve is injured.
questions.solution:
This the case of ANTERIOR DISLOCATION oh arm

In this there is loss of skin sensation in the lower half of the deltoid region which is supplyed by axilary nerve

The most commone nerve injury in ANTERIOR DISLOCATION is AXILLARY NERVE

In POSTERIOR DISLOCATION -AXIKKARY ARTERY IS INJURED

AXILLARY NERVE:

Supplys: DELTOID MUSCLE

TERES MINOR MUSCLE

Sensory supply: skin on the UPPER Lateral side of ARM

choices.text: Compression of the median nerve in the car pal tunnel
Formation of the osteophytes that compress the ulnar nerve at the ulnar condyle
Hypertrophy of the triceps muscle compressing the brachial plexus

questions.text: A 68-year-old man has numbness and pain in the middle three digits of his hand at night. right He retired 8 years ago after working as a carpenter for 30 years. He has atrophy of the thenar eminence (see figure below). Which of the following conditions will be the most likely cause of this atrophy?
questions.solution:
The median nerve supplies sensory innervation to the thumb, index, and middle finger as well as to the lateral half of the ring finger. The median nerve also provides motor innervation to muscles of the thenar eminence. Compression of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel explains these deficits in conjunction with normal functioning of the flexor compartment of the forearm. The ulnar nerve is not implicated in these symptoms.

Compression of the brachial plexus could not be attributed to pressure from hypertrophy of the triceps, it is located distal to the plexus. In addition, symptoms would include several upper limb deficits rather than the focal symptoms described in this instance. Osteoarthritis of the cervical spine would also lead to increasing complexity of symptoms.

questions.text: A patient woke up from sleep with difficulty in extending fingers. He can make a grip and hold a pen. Wrist extension was possible. No sensory disturbance was found. Injury could be at
questions.solution: Posterior interosseus nerve injury leads to paralysis of Extensor Digitorum. Clinically patient will present with inability to extend fingers but able to extend wrist and elbow. Its pure motor injury so no sensory loss

questions.text: An 86 - year - old man has trouble while walking. At his physicians office, he is asked to stand on his right foot and his left hip drops. Which of the following nerves is most likely damaged, causing his problem:
questions.solution: In this patient, the right superior gluteal nerve is damaged, leading to failure of abductor mechanism of gluteus medius. There is also the failure of muscle to cause an upward lift of the left hip, when the patient is asked to stand on his right foot. Normally the superior gluteal nerve leads to pelvic stability while a person stands on a single foot, by elevating the opposite hip - the job being performed by gluteus medius.

questions.text: A 42- year - old female presents with chronic upper gastrointestinal complaints. Upper Gl endoscopy shows proliferating mass in the stomach and she was eventually diagnosed to have gastric carcinoma. During surgery, before approaching the stomach, lesser omentum is seen. Free edge of lesser omentum is formed by:
questions.solution:
All of these Free edge of lesser omentum contains the structures that enter the porta hepatis.

D - Duct (bile),

A - Artery (hepatic),

V - Vein (portal).

These structures form the anterior boundary of epiploic foramen.

questions.text: In portal hypertension lower end of the esophagus shows dilatation of veins. Which of the following veins drains into the portal vein from the lower end of the esophagus:
questions.solution:
At lower end of esophagus, porto-caval anastomosis in between:

(i) Tributary of portal vein → Left gastric

(ii) Systemic vein → esophageal vein

questions.text: The gland shown below is supplied through a parasympathetic system. It is supplied by which of the following ganglion?
questions.solution:
The pterygopalatine ganglion supplies the lacrimal gland, paranasal sinuses, glands of the mucosa of the nasal cavity and pharynx, the gingiva, and the mucous membrane and glands of the hard palate.

It communicates anteriorly with the nasopalatine nerve.

choices.text: At the level of cricopharyngeal sphincter
At the crossing of aortic arch
At the crossing of left bronchus
At the level of opening in the diaphragm

questions.text: Esophagus is constricted at 4 anatomic locations. Narrowest part of esophagus lies at which of the following constriction?
questions.solution:
Narrowest part of esophagus is at its commencement at the cricopharyngeal sphincter which is 15cm from the incisor teeth.

Other sites of esophagus where it is slightly constricted includes:

Crossing by the aortic arch which is 22cm from the teeth.

Crossing by the left principal bronchus which is 27cm from the teeth At the opening in the diaphragm which is 38cm from the teeth

questions.text: A patient presents with an episode of unconscious followed by consciousness after he got into a fight, an immediate NCCT is done and it shows a biconvex hyperdense blood collection. Doctor informs the patient that this is due to rupture of an artery in his brain, which of the following structures does this artery pass via?
questions.solution: Biconvex hyperdense blood collection refers to EDH which is due to rupture of the middle meningeal artery; this artery passes by foramen spinosum.

questions.text: While doing surgery for meningioma on cerebral hemisphere, there occurred injury to left paracentral lobule; it will lead to paresis of:
questions.solution: Para central lobule lies on the medial aspect of cerebral hemispheres around the central sulcus As per homunculus the body is represented upside down in the contralateral cerebral hemisphere, and the leg area is located in the paracentral lobule

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with chest pain, dyspnea, and weight loss. Chest X-ray showed an elevated right dome of the diaphragm. CT revealed a tumor invading the right lung surface anterior to the hilum. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved by the tumor?
questions.solution:
The right phrenic nerve is involved by the tumor as it passes anterior to the hilum of the lung.

The phrenic nerve provides the sole motor supply to the diaphragm. Normally, the diaphragm flattens when it contracts.

Involvement of the phrenic nerve causes elevation of the respective dome of the diaphragm.

questions.text: A 22-year-old basketball player injured his foot during training and is admitted to the emergency department. An MRI examination reveals the presence of hematoma in the medial malleolus. Upon physical examination the patient shows over eversion of his foot. Which of the following ligaments most likely has a tear?
questions.solution: Deltoid ligament prevents the over eversion of ankle. it is so strong that excessive eversion can cause the medial malleolus to be pulled off (an avulsion fracture

questions.text:
Arrange lung hilar structures from anterior to posterior:

1. Primary bronchus
2. Bronchial artery
3. Pulmonary vein
4. Pulmonary artery
questions.solution:
Lung hilar structures are arranged from the anterior to posterior in the order:

  • Pulmonary vein
  • Pulmonary artery
  • primary bronchus
  • Bronchial artery

The medial surface of the lung is connected to the heart and trachea by a group of structures that enter or leave the hilum. It is called the pulmonary root. It is anteriorly related to the phrenic nerve, pericardiophrenic vessels, and anterior pulmonary plexus. The vagus nerve and posterior pulmonary plexus form the posterior relation and the pulmonary ligament the inferior relation.

The superior vena cava and right atrium are seen in front of the right root and terminal part of the azygos vein superiorly. The hilar structures are arranged from the superior to inferior as:

  • Superior lobar bronchus
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

questions.text: A 7 year old child patient presents with enlarged abdomen, On evaluation the child reports that he is having a dragging sensation in her abdomen. Examination confirms the presence of splenomegaly reaching 15cms below the costal margin. Which structure prevents spleen from descending vertically down ?
questions.solution: A fold of peritoneum, the phrenicocolic ligament is continued from the left colic flexure to the thoracic diaphragm opposite the tenth and eleventh ribs; it passes below and serves to support the spleen. It is not attached to spleen but supports its anterior end & prevents its downward displacement in splenomegaly. So, the spleen tends to extend downward & medially towards right iliac fossa.

questions.text: During the embryological development, the midgut rotates a total of in the intrauterine life
questions.solution:
During development, midgut undergoes rapid phase of growth in which loops of midgut herniate outside the abdominal cavity of fetus & protrude into umbilical cord

This is PHYSIOLOGICAL UMBILICAL HERNIA (occurs at 6 weeks of IUL) At week 10, it comes back to abdominal cavity.

When midgut s Herniating into umbilicus, it follows superior mesenteric artery Thus, superior mesenteric artery becomes axis of rotation.

While entering umbilical cord there is:

  • High point: duodenojejunal junction (small intestine).
  • Low point: ileocecal junction (large intestine).
  • Which rotates 1st 90 degree anti- clock wise resulting in small intestine to right side & large intestine to left side.
  • While coming back to abdominal cavity, there would be another 180 degree anti - clock wise rotation.
  • Total of 270 degree anti-clock wise rotation occurs during development of midgut in IUL.
  • Duodenum become C shaped and have 4 parts and colon will also have 4 parts (Ascending, transverse & descending & sigmoid colon).

questions.text: Mammillary body is a structure on the undersurface of the brain, developing from the diencephalon, that forms a part of the limbic system. They receive afferent fibers via the:-
questions.solution:
• Mammillary body receives afferent fibers via Fornix.
  • C-shaped bundle of nerve fibers which acts as major output tract of the hippocampus.
  • They are association fibers(connects one brain center to another).
  • It is a part of limbic system (Papez circuit).
  • Papez circuit for memory consolidation, emotions & behavior.
